author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Hispanic Heritage Month In Philadelphia Brings A Feast Of FiestasTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Hispanic Heritage Month In Philadelphia Brings A Feast Of Fiestas Published on : Wednesday, August 19, 2015
Visitors don’t have to dig deep to find lots to do during Hispanic Heritage Month festivities (September 15-October 15). Festivities are on tap for the groundbreaking of El Corazon Cultural Center, Taller Puertorriqueño’s long-awaited community arts center.
Plus,revelers can catch the party spirit at Penn’s Landing’s Mexican Independence Day Festival and the Puerto Rican Day Parade on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. For event updates, follow @PhillyTeAma on Twitter for all of Philly’s Hispanic Heritage Month happenings.
Parties, Parades & Festivals:
It’s all Mexico, all day—food, music, dancing and crafts—during the annual Mexican Independence Day Festival at Penn’s Landing. The family-friendly affair includes performances by a mariachi band and a dance troupe, as well as local and national food and drink vendors, including Taquitos de Puebla, El Sarape and Los Gallos. September 13. Great Plaza at Penn’s Landing, Columbus Boulevard at Chestnut Street, (215) 922-2386,
Did someone say fiesta? Look no further than the annual Feria del Barrio, one of Philadelphia’s largest celebrations of Latino art and culture. Historic Centro de Oro will be a joyous jumble of free music, dance, art and other activities for the whole family. September 13. 5th Street between Lehigh Avenue & Cambria Street, (215) 426-3311,
Get ready to dance, dance, dance at Brazilian Day Philadelphia, celebrating Brazil’s independence. Authentic foods and merchandise are available in abundance, and performers light up the stage with the rhythms of the samba, forro, pagode, capoeira, samba-reggae and other dances. September 20. Great Plaza at Penn’s Landing, Columbus Boulevard at Chestnut Street, (215) 922-2386.
Floats, festive dances, local celebs, youth groups and more than 1,500 musicians spice up the action on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway for the Puerto Rican Day Parade. The annual parade is the city’s largest and oldest outdoor event celebrating Latino and Puerto Rican heritage. September 27. Benjamin Franklin Parkway, (215) 627-3100
As part of the Mural Arts Program’s Open Source project, artists Ernel Martinez and Keir Johnston collaborated on La Frontera, an installation piece designed to transform an empty warehouse space into a pop-up bodega that hosts community-centric programs. The masterpiece’s debut takes place at the North Philly Block Party, uniting the community for a day full of entertainment, surprise guests and giveaways. October 3. 9th Street & Susquehanna Avenue, (215) 685-0750.
It’s glitz and glamour galore when Philadelphia’s who’s who hit the red carpet for the annual Hispanic Choice Awards. The event celebrates the accomplishments of leaders and influencers from diverse industries who have made a difference and inspired others. October 3. Merriam Theater, 250 S. Broad Street.
Art & Culture:
The National Constitution Center celebrates Hispanic-American Trailblazers all month long. A new interactive show, Paving New Ground, engages visitors as they explore the lives of such noted citizens as author Oscar Hijuelos and educator Jaime Escalante. While at the center, visitors can also check out the giant game board and test their knowledge of Hispanic-American history. September 15-October 15 (programs not offered September 17). 525 Arch Street, (215) 409-6700.
After 10 years of planning, the first shovel will dig in for the groundbreaking of Taller Puertorriqueño’s new El Corazon Cultural Center, the largest Puerto Rican/Latino-based arts and cultural facility in Pennsylvania. Once open in 2016, the center will host social events, exhibitions, classes, play activities and more. September 18. 2600-2624 N. 5th Street.
The Barnes Foundation turns up the heat on First Friday with a musical journey featuring Dos y Mas (Two and More). Percussionist Arturo Stable and pianist Elio Villafranca rock the halls with their explosive Cuban-influenced rhythms. October 2. 2025 Benjamin Franklin Parkway, (215) 278-7000.
Heroes, scoundrels, diplomacy and intrigue. It’s all part of American Revolutions – How Spain and Her Colonies Saved the United States, a ranger-led walking tour through some of Philadelphia’s most historic streets. In just 45 minutes, visitors learn about the American Revolution of the Hispanic diplomats whose 18th-century heroics helped shape a modern nation. October 10-11, 17-18, 24-25. Departs from the Signer’s Garden, 5th & Chestnut Streets, (215) 965-2305.
Anytime is a good time to visit the Mexico and Central America Galleries at the Penn Museum. Five grand stone monuments with hieroglyphic writing and two monumental circular altars from the Penn Museum’s early Maya excavations dominate this signature gallery. Also on view: more than 200 ancient artifacts such as jade carvings, jewelry, painted pottery and figurines, some dating back 3,500 years. 3260 South Street, (215) 898-4000.
Source:- Philadelphia
